snippet: A case taken up by the Supreme Court concerns whether trustees for a corporate 401(k) are liable years after choosing a class of mutual fund with higher fees.
abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column examines Supreme Court case in which employees of Edison International have sued company over decision by trustees to invest 401(k) contributions in funds with higher management fees; notes that decision saved costs for company, increasing its bottom line at the expense of employee investment returns; holds that case turns on interpretation of 1974 law that set rules for corporate plans in an era when nearly all of them were defined-benefit plans rather than market-based 401(k).
lead_paragraph: A case taken up by the Supreme Court concerns whether trustees for a corporate 401(k) are liable years after choosing a class of mutual fund with higher fees.

headline.print_headline: What a Plan Really Owes Employees
headline.main: What a 401(k) Plan Really Owes Employees
